intro: Corchorus trinervis, commonly known as the three-veined spurge, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa and Asia. It is a herbaceous annual that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring alternate, lanceolate leaves with three prominent veins. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in spikes, which are often clustered at the ends of the stems. Its roots are fibrous and can be harvested for use in traditional medicine and as a source of fiber. The species is valued for its adaptability to poor soils and its role in local ecosystems.
